newsitem.title: PHILIPPINES: PHILIPPINE STOCKS - factors to watch - May 2.
newsitem.headline: PHILIPPINE STOCKS - factors to watch - May 2.

text.p: Following are views on the direction of Philippine stocks on Friday and main factors likely to affect trading.

* Philippine shares are seen to pursuing their downward bias on a lack of investor confidence in the overall market helped by the Dow's and PLDT's fall in New York, Ramon Saulo, senior investment analyst at Asiamerit Securities said.
* The downtrend is likely to continue as investors doubt positive first quarter earnings of property and banking firms can be sustained, said Anscor-Hagedorn research head Noel Reyes.
* The Philippine share market was closed on Thursday due to a public holiday for the Labour Day celebration. On Wednesday, the main stock market index plunged by 60.27 points at 2,648.17.
* On Thursday, the Dow Jones shed 32.51 points to 6,976.48 at 10.28125 percent.
* Jollibee Foods Corp said its net income for the first three months of the year rose by 10 percent to 121.094 million pesos from 109.818 million.
* Singapore's Keppel Corp has outbid Bank Lippo for control of the ailing Monte de Piedad and Savings Bank.
* Robinson's Land Corp said its net income for the fiscal year 1996/97 is expected to climb by over 50 percent.
* Shareholders of Benpres Holdings Corp approved the transfer of media units ABS-CBN Broadcasting Corp and Sky-Vision Corp to unlisted parent Lopez Inc.

* Empire East Land Holdings Inc said it posted a 16 percent rise in first quarter profits this year to 349.2 million pesos from 301.3 million. Its parent firm, Megaworld Properties & Holdings Inc said its net income for the first three months was at 419 million pesos from the previous year's 369 million.
* Fil-Estate Land Inc said its net income for the first six months of its fiscal year ending March was at 1,236 million pesos from 908 million a year-ago.
* SM Prime Holdings Inc said its net income for the first three months of 1997 rose to 497.3 million pesos from 404.5 million the same period in 1996.
* Jardine Davies Inc reported a sharp rise in net income for the first quarter of 1997 at 237.978 million pesos compared with previous year's 8.035 million.
* Basic Petroleum & Minerals Inc said it expects net income for 1997 to reach 108.56 million pesos this year from 7.56 million in 1996 due to its non-oil activities.
* The Philippine Central Bank said that there was no capital flight following the tumble in the local equities market.

* Manila Bulletin says consumers may expect prices of most petroleum products to drop in the next two weeks as prices of Singapore Posted Prices, the benchmark used for monthly oil price adjustments, continue to post declines.

* Newspaper BusinessWorld said that the energy unit of the Philippine National Oil Co, the PNOC-Energy Development Corp, will start looking for a global coordinator this month to assist in its privatisation efforts. The Committee on Privatisation said it has approved the initial public offering of PNOC-EDC in September.
* The Philippine peso closed unchanged at 26.370 to the dollar
* The Philippine interbank call loan average remained steady
